title: Mental health property sector set to take off
text:
Initially, the facility will house up to 52 beds and will grow to up to 80 beds.

"What we found in Canberra, in terms of mental health beds there were 20, for adolescents, zero," Barwon Investment Partners director Rob Morrison said.

The surge into healthcare is part of a broader trend to invest in real estate that underpins demographic and social growth trends, as capital diversifies from the traditional commercial property assets.

The emerging sector is attractive due to its higher yields compared to offices, retail and industrial assets.

Income certainty

"If you look at traditional asset classes like offices, they may churn 100 basis points in incentives and lease renewals. That runs close to zero in healthcare," Mr Mitchell said.

"So a 5 per cent cap rate in healthcare is a 4 per cent equivalent cap rate in offices."

Institutional investors such as superannuation funds would find that particularly irresistible as they looked to secure the income certainty, Mr Morrison said.

Advertisement

Insurance companies also provide an impetus for the growth of the non-hospital medical and aged-care facilities, as do the governments that are trying to preserve hospitals for those with acute needs.

"Day surgeries – we don't have a lot of those – but health insurers in Australia will say it is 23 per cent cheaper to a procedure in a day surgery versus a private hospital," Mr Mitchell said.

"That's $250 million a year in savings on health insurance. That is an example of how mixing and matching works for us."

The building of medical precincts around a public hospital also offered further investment opportunities, panellists said.
description: "A 5 per cent cap rate in healthcare is a 4 per cent equivalent cap rate in offices": NorthWest Healthcare Properties Australia and NZ's Craig Mitchell
